bestBHT.bht: That I may come unto you with joy by the will of God, and may with you find rest, after all his labors and anxieties, and be refitted for future service. We cannot doubt that the Apostle’s arrival at Rome was 'in joy,' even though in bonds, since in all he submitted himself to the will of God.

Henry Alford: 32.] and may with you find rest ‘that we may mutually refresh ourselves, I after my dangers and: deliverance, you after your anxieties for me.’
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: That I may come unto you with joy by the will of God.
With you refresh myself, after all his labors and anxieties.
So be refitted for future service.
Albert Barnes: With joy - Joy to myself in being permitted to come; and producing joy to you by my presence.
After all his desires, and all their prayers, it still depended on the will of God; and to that the apostle was desirous to submit.
This should be the end of our most ardent desires, and this the object of all our prayers, that the will of God should be done.
Marvin Vincent: With you be refreshed [συναναπαυσωμαι υμιν] . See on give rest, Matthew 11:28.
Philip Schaff: That in joy (the emphasis rests on this phrase)...
I may together with you find rest.

The reality was entirely different from this hope and prayer; but we cannot doubt that the Apostle’s arrival at Rome was ‘in joy,’ even though in bonds, since in all he submitted himself to the will of God.
Archibald T. Robertson: First use of ινα in this sentence, the first one sub-final (ινα ρυσθω), this one final with συναναπαυσωμα" [100 words]
First aorist middle subjunctive of the double compound verb συναναπαυομα, late verb to rest together with, to refresh (αναπαυω as in Matthew 11:28) one's spirit with (συν)" [100 words]
With the associative instrumental case υμιν (with you), only here in the N.T." [28 words]
John Gill: That I may come unto you with joy...he might hope they would be the more importunate in their supplications for him, that he might escape their hands.
seeing also, should the saints there use him in an ungrateful manner... his coming to them would be with sorrow.
and may with you be refreshed...nothing is more reviving, and refreshing to the spirits of God's people.
John Wesley: That I may come to you — This refers to the former, With joy - To the latter, part of the preceding verse.

bhtAttempts.bht: That I may come unto you with joy by the will of God, and may with you find rest after all his labors and anxieties, so be refitted for future service, that we may mutually refresh ourselves. This should be the end of our most ardent desires, and this the object of all our prayers, that the will of God should be done. The Apostle's arrival at Rome was 'in joy,' even though in bonds, since in all he submitted himself to the will of God.

That I may come unto you with joy by the will of God, and may with you find rest after all his labors and anxieties. This should be the end of our most ardent desires, and this the object of all our prayers, that the will of God should be done. The Apostle's arrival at Rome was 'in joy,' even though in bonds, since in all he submitted himself to the will of God.

That I may come unto you with joy by the will of God, and may with you find rest, after all his labors and anxieties, and be refitted for future service. This should be the end of our most ardent desires, and this the object of all our prayers, that the will of God should be done. The reality was entirely different from this hope and prayer; but we cannot doubt that the Apostle’s arrival at Rome was 'in joy,' even though in bonds, since in all he submitted himself to the will of God.

That I may come unto you with joy by the will of God, and may with you find rest, after all his labors and anxieties, and be refitted for future service. We cannot doubt that the Apostle’s arrival at Rome was 'in joy,' even though in bonds, since in all he submitted himself to the will of God.

That I may come unto you with joy by the will of God, and may with you find rest. The apostle Paul expresses his desire to be united with the Romans and find solace in their fellowship after his toils and dangers. This mutual refreshing and restoration is of utmost importance as they work together for the furtherance of God's Kingdom. Their prayers and God's will determine the outcome, and they trust that the apostle's arrival at Rome will be filled with joy, even in the midst of his bonds, for he submits himself to the sovereign plan of God.
